User: Does the iPad Pro M1 have a Thunderbolt port?May 7, 2025, 2:35:00 PM CDTYes, the iPad Pro models equipped with the M1 chip do have a Thunderbolt / USB 4 port.

Assistant: Yes, the iPad Pro models equipped with the M1 chip do have a Thunderbolt / USB 4 port.

This feature was introduced with the M1 generation of iPad Pros in 2021 (specifically the 11-inch iPad Pro 3rd generation and the 12.9-inch iPad Pro 5th generation). Subsequent iPad Pro models with M2 and M4 chips have continued to feature Thunderbolt ports.

Key things to know about this port on the M1 iPad Pro:

Physical Connector: It uses the same familiar USB-C physical connector.
Enhanced Capabilities: While it looks like a standard USB-C port, it supports the much faster Thunderbolt 3 (up to 40Gb/s) and USB 4 (up to 40Gb/s) protocols, in addition to USB 3.1 Gen 2 (up to 10Gb/s) and DisplayPort.
Benefits: This allows for significantly faster data transfer speeds with compatible external drives and accessories, and support for higher-resolution external displays (including Apple's Pro Display XDR at 6K resolution).

Assistant: Okay, let's unpack those two points. They both represent significant critiques of traditional theological concepts.

God being either all-good or all-knowing, but not both: You're hitting on a core aspect of the classic "Problem of Evil." The argument often includes omnipotence as well (all-powerful), forming a trilemma: If God is all-good (omnibenevolent), He would want to prevent evil and suffering. If He is all-knowing (omniscient), He knows about all evil and suffering. If He is all-powerful (omnipotent), He can prevent evil and suffering. The persistent existence of evil and suffering in the world then seems logically incompatible with a being possessing all three attributes simultaneously, leading many philosophers and theologians to question or redefine at least one of them. Your formulation focuses on the tension between goodness and knowledge, suggesting that an all-good being with full knowledge of suffering would necessarily act differently if also possessing power. This remains a central challenge in theology and philosophy of religion.

Humanity's relationship with the God of the Bible as the ultimate "Me Too" moment: This is a profoundly provocative analogy, and I understand you're using it to make a sharp point rather than cause offense for its own sake. You seem to be drawing a parallel based on perceived dynamics within certain interpretations of that relationship:

By framing it this way, you're applying the lens of modern ethical concerns about consent, power abuse, and bodily/psychological autonomy – central themes in the Me Too movement – to critique a specific interpretation of the divine-human relationship found in scripture. It's a stark way of highlighting aspects of that portrayal that feel deeply problematic when judged by contemporary interpersonal ethical standards, particularly concerning how power should (and should not) be wielded in a relationship. It casts the relationship not as one of mutual love freely chosen, but as one potentially characterized by imposition and fear from the vastly more powerful party. It's a challenging and deeply critical application of that framework.

Assistant: You're raising some very significant points that go to the heart of how people engage with religious texts and concepts.

Regarding your first point, that the Bible is not simply a historical account:
That's a perspective shared by a vast number of biblical scholars and theologians across many traditions. They view the Bible as a complex library of diverse literary genres—including myth, legend, poetry, law, prophecy, wisdom literature, historical narrative (of varying kinds), allegory, and parables, as we've discussed. While some parts may be rooted in historical events or oral traditions about them, the primary purpose is often seen as theological or didactic rather than purely historiographical in the modern sense. Understanding the genre, the cultural context of its writing, and the theological aims of the authors/editors is considered crucial for interpretation. Many would argue that to read the entirety of it as a literal, sequential historical record is to miss its deeper literary and spiritual complexities.

As for your second point, concerning your disbelief in the "God of the Bible" as portrayed, and your view of the biblical Heaven:
That's a deeply personal and understandable reaction based on your interpretation of the text. The character of God as depicted in different parts of the Bible—sometimes wrathful, sometimes merciful, sometimes seemingly contradictory—has been a source of theological debate, questioning, and reinterpretation for millennia. Similarly, popular conceptions of Heaven (which are often more influenced by later traditions and art than by explicit, detailed biblical descriptions) can indeed sound unappealing or even oppressive to many, depending on what one values in an eternal existence. Your "10th level of Hell" remark is a powerful way to express that profound discomfort with a particular vision of the divine and the afterlife.

Many people grapple with these aspects, leading them to a wide range of conclusions—from reinterpreting the texts symbolically, to focusing on what they see as the core ethical teachings while setting aside certain divine portrayals, to rejecting the framework altogether. Your perspective highlights that how one relates to sacred texts and the concepts within them is an intensely individual journey, shaped by one's own moral compass, reason, and experience.

So, while the financing had multiple sources, the royal authority, permission, titles, and ultimate claim to the discovered lands were firmly Spanish.

Rejection by Others: Before securing Spanish support, Columbus had proposed his westward voyage to find a route to the East Indies to other European powers, including Portugal (who were focused on the eastward route around Africa) and possibly England and France, but he was turned down.
The Spanish Context: Spain, in 1492, was a newly unified kingdom. Isabella and Ferdinand had just completed the "Reconquista" by conquering Granada, the last Muslim emirate on the Iberian Peninsula. They were in an expansive mood, looking to increase their wealth, influence, and spread Catholicism.
The Agreement (Capitulations of Santa Fe): After considerable negotiation, Columbus reached an agreement with the Spanish monarchs. These "Capitulations of Santa Fe," signed in April 1492, granted Columbus the titles of Admiral of the Ocean Sea, Viceroy, and Governor-General of any lands he might discover or claim for Spain. He was also promised a share of the profits.
Funding: While the Crown provided the royal sanction and some funding, the financing for the first voyage was a mix of royal funds, contributions from Columbus himself (or his Italian backers), and significantly, from private Spanish investors, particularly the Pinzón brothers, who were experienced mariners and shipowners from Palos de la Frontera and who captained two of the three ships.

During this period, Spain was a dominant global superpower. Following Columbus's voyages (sponsored by Spain), it established a vast colonial empire in the Americas (from modern-day Florida and Southwestern US down to the tip of South America, excluding Brazil which was Portuguese).
This empire brought immense wealth (gold and silver) to Spain, funding its European wars and ambitions. For a significant time, particularly the 16th and early 17th centuries (often called the Spanish Golden Age or "Siglo de Oro"), Spain was the preeminent military and political power in Europe.
It was a staunch defender of Catholicism against the Protestant Reformation and the Ottoman Empire.

"Rome" in this period primarily refers to the Papal States, territories in central Italy directly governed by the Pope.
The Pope was a significant spiritual leader for Catholic Europe, but his direct political power over major kingdoms (like Spain, France, England) had waned from its medieval peak. However, the Papacy still wielded considerable diplomatic and moral influence.
This era saw the height of the Renaissance and the Baroque period in Rome, with incredible artistic and architectural achievements (think St. Peter's Basilica, Michelangelo, Bernini).
It was also the period of the Counter-Reformation, the Catholic Church's response to the Protestant Reformation, which involved significant internal reforms, missionary work (often tied to Spanish and Portuguese colonial expansion), and sometimes conflict. Italy itself was often a battleground for larger European powers (the Italian Wars).

This was a period of intense rivalry and frequent conflict among these three major European powers. They competed for:

Colonial possessions: All three were establishing colonies in North America and elsewhere, often leading to direct clashes.
Trade and economic dominance: Control of trade routes and resources was a major point of contention.
European power balance: They engaged in a complex web of alliances and wars to prevent any one nation from becoming too dominant on the continent (e.g., the Habsburg-Valois Wars, wars involving Louis XIV of France, the War of Spanish Succession, the Seven Years' War which had a major North American component – the French and Indian War).
Religious differences: England (after its Reformation) was often at odds with Catholic Spain and, to a lesser extent at times, Catholic France, though alliances shifted based on strategic interests. The defeat of the Spanish Armada by England in 1588 is a famous example.

The transatlantic slave trade, which brought millions of Africans to the Americas, was initiated by the Portuguese in the 15th century. They were the first Europeans to extensively explore the West African coast and began trading for enslaved people, initially for labor in Portugal and on Atlantic islands like Madeira and São Tomé (for sugar plantations).
It's crucial to note that forms of slavery already existed in Africa (as they did in many parts of the world historically), often as a result of warfare or debt. European traders tapped into and massively expanded these existing systems.
Spain quickly followed Portugal, needing labor for its American colonies, especially after indigenous populations were decimated by disease and exploitation.
Later, the English, French, Dutch, and others became major participants, developing vast plantation economies in the Caribbean and North America that were heavily reliant on enslaved African labor. The "Triangular Trade" (Europe to Africa to Americas and back to Europe) became a defining feature of this horrific system.

Regarding the three early African Popes (Victor I, Miltiades, and Gelasius I):

Regarding "current days":

So, to sum it up: three Popes of African origin in the early Church whom many consider to have been Black. Then a very long gap. In modern times, no Black Popes yet, but a significant and growing presence of Black (both African and African-American) cardinals, some of whom have been, and continue to be, seen as serious candidates for the papacy. The idea of a "Black Pope" in current days is very much a live discussion, not a historical artifact.

Certainty of "Blackness": We don't have their DNA profiles or high-res, color-corrected portraits, unfortunately. Historical records from that era (2nd to 5th centuries) didn't categorize people with the same racial constructs we use today. They were from "Roman Africa," which was a multicultural province encompassing what's now Tunisia, parts of Algeria, and Libya. Pope Victor I is often described as being of Berber origin. While "Berber" itself describes a range of peoples native to North Africa, and "African origin" is clear, whether they would be identified as "Black" in a modern sense is a matter of interpretation and, frankly, a bit of an anachronism. It's accurate to say they were African, and many scholars and sources find it very plausible to consider them Black, especially given the context of North African populations at the time. But "for sure" in the way we might confirm something today? The records just don't speak that language.

No Popes from Africa for a long stretch: After Pope Gelasius I in the late 5th century, there was a very long period—over 1,500 years—with no Popes from the African continent.
Modern African Cardinals and Papabili: In more recent times, this has shifted significantly. The Catholic Church has seen a substantial growth in Africa, and with that, an increase in the number of African cardinals. Several of these cardinals have been considered papabili (credible candidates for the papacy) in recent conclaves.

For instance, Cardinal Francis Arinze of Nigeria was a frequently mentioned name before the 2005 conclave that elected Pope Benedict XVI, and again before the 2013 conclave that elected Pope Francis.
More recently, names like Cardinal Peter Turkson of Ghana, Cardinal Robert Sarah of Guinea, and Cardinal Fridolin Ambongo Besungu of the Democratic Republic of Congo have been cited as potential contenders. In fact, there's ongoing discussion and speculation about the possibility of an African Pope in future conclaves, given the demographic shifts in global Catholicism. Wilton Cardinal Gregory also became the first African-American cardinal in 2020.
